content: The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" is cited as the Act. It excludes space-related income from gross income according to an amendment in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Space-related income includes income from products or services produced in outer space, services performed in outer space, and certain interest, rent, or royalties related to space activities. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes income from products or services produced in outer space, services performed in outer space, and certain interest, rent, or royalties related to space activities. There are exceptions for telecommunications services, services provided by satellites, and transporting property to or from outer space. Wages received by employees are also exempt. Space-related income is proportionally allocated between space-based and earth-based activities. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes products manufactured in outer space, which are exempt from Federal excises, imposts, and tariffs if launched from or manufactured at a facility owned by United States persons. The Act also defines "produced" to include various methods such as created, fabricated, developed, grown, and manufactured. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts space-related income from Federal taxes if products are launched from or manufactured at a facility owned by US persons. The benefits phase out after 2012, reducing the exclusion amount based on the number of years since 2013. A clerical amendment is made to the tax code sections. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts space-related income from Federal taxes for products launched or manufactured at US-owned facilities. A new section, SEC. 45G, provides a credit for purchasing qualified space company stock. Effective after December 31, 2003. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts space-related income from Federal taxes for products launched or manufactured at US-owned facilities. Section 45G offers a credit for buying qualified space company stock. Qualified space company must meet specific criteria regarding gross receipts and space-based business income. The term 'space-based business' refers to a business with gross receipts primarily from space-related income. Rules similar to section 1202(d)(3) apply for aggregation. Qualified stock in a domestic C corporation is defined as stock acquired from a qualified space company at its original issue in exchange for money, property, or as compensation for services. During the taxpayer's holding period, qualified stock in a C corporation must meet active business requirements similar to section 1202(e) for space-based businesses. Rules similar to section 1202(c)(3) apply for certain purchases of the corporation's own stock. Recapture may occur if qualified stock is sold within 10 years of purchase. The tax credit for space company investments in qualified stock of a C corporation is subject to recapture if the issuer ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years of purchase. This provision does not apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2011. The credit is included as part of the general business credit under Section 38(b) of the tax code. The tax credit for space company investments in qualified stock of a C corporation is subject to recapture if the issuer ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years of purchase. This credit is part of the general business credit under Section 38(b) of the tax code, with amendments made to allow for the space company investment credit. Amendments also restrict the carryback of this credit before January 1, 2004. The tax code is amended to include the space company investment credit under section 45G(a) for qualified stock purchases. The credit is subject to recapture if the issuer no longer qualifies as a space company within 10 years. Carryback of the credit is restricted before January 1, 2004. The tax code is amended to include a space company investment credit under section 45G for qualified stock purchases. The amendments apply to costs incurred after December 31, 2003. Additionally, a capital gains exclusion is introduced for gains from the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations under section 1203. The tax code now includes a capital gains exclusion for the sale of stock in qualified space corporations. These corporations must be C corporations organized for providing products or services in outer space, with at least 90% of expenses related to this business activity. The tax code now allows for a capital gains exclusion on the sale of stock in qualified space corporations, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2003.
